title: FishVis - A regional decision support tool
subTitle: FishVis, a regional decision support tool
summary: Fish sample collections and environmental variables from multiple sources across the United States Great Lakes Basin were integrated and used to develop empirical models to predict fish species occurrence under present-day climate conditions. Random Forests models were used to predict the probability of occurrence of 13 lotic fish species within each stream reach in the study area. Downscaled climate data from general circulation models were integrated with the fish species occurrence models to project fish species occurrence under future climate conditions.  Model Name (Name of the model, including acronyms): FishVis Model Version (Version of the model, (i.e., 2.0)): 1.0 Abstract (Description or summary of the model, including its [...]
body:
Fish sample collections and environmental variables from multiple sources across the United States Great Lakes Basin were integrated and used to develop empirical models to predict fish species occurrence under present-day climate conditions. Random Forests models were used to predict the probability of occurrence of 13 lotic fish species within each stream reach in the study area. Downscaled climate data from general circulation models were integrated with the fish species occurrence models to project fish species occurrence under future climate conditions.

Model Name (Name of the model, including acronyms):

FishVis

Model Version (Version of the model, (i.e., 2.0)):

1.0

Abstract (Description or summary of the model, including its purpose or goals and the type or formalism of the model (e.g., system dynamic, agent based model, machine learning), preferably accompanied by relevant keywords):

Fish sample collections and environmental variables from multiple sources across the United States Great Lakes Basin were integrated and used to develop empirical models to predict fish species occurrence under present-day climate conditions. Random Forests models were used to predict the probability of occurrence of 13 lotic fish species within each stream reach in the study area. Downscaled climate data from general circulation models were integrated with the fish species occurrence models to project fish species occurrence under future climate conditions.

Originator(s) (Name(s) of the model developer(s)/author(s)):

Jana Stewart (USGS), Nicholas Estes (USGS), Daniel J Wieferich (USGS)

Contact Name(s) (Person(s) responsible for maintenance of the model):

Release Date (Date model was originally released (MM, YYYY)):

10, 2017

Last Update (Date of last update (MM, YYYY)):

10, 2017

Organization(s) (Organization(s) that produced, funded, or partnered on the creation of this model):

USGS

Mission Area _(USGS mission area with which this model most clearly aligns. https://www.usgs.gov/science/mission-areas)_:100:

Core Science Systems

License (OSI-approved (Open-Source Initiative) license (see https://opensource.org/licenses)):

https://github.com/USGS-WiM/FishVis/blob/master/LICENSE.md

Language (Computer language or platform used for programming (e.g., Fortan, R, Python))↕

ActionScript, JavaScript

Resources (Resources (how to use the model, where to download it, related publications, other webpages about the model (in other catalogs), USGS webpage):

Stewart, J.S., Covert, S.A., Estes, N.J., Westenbroek, S.M., Krueger, Damon, Wieferich, D.J., Slattery, M.T., Lyons, J.D., McKenna, J.E., Jr., Infante, D.M., and Bruce, J.L., 2016, FishVis, A regional decision support tool for identifying vulnerabilities of riverine habitat and fishes to climate change in the Great Lakes Region: U.S. Geological Survey Scientific Investigations Report 2016–5124, 15 p., https://doi.org/10.3133/sir20165124.
